ContentsSchedule.ContentsTitle: Employment allowance: rules for determining if persons are “connected”
Office holders in receipt of “earnings” to be employed earners: consequential provision

Para.Text: Make provision in relation to national insurance contributions; and for connected purposes.

Be it enacted by the Queen’s most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, as follows:—

P1group.Title: Employment allowance for national insurance contributions

P2para.Text: A person qualifies for an employment allowance for a tax year if, in the tax year—

P3para.Text: the person is the secondary contributor in relation to payments of earnings to, or for the benefit of, one or more employed earners, and
in consequence, the person incurs liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions,

P2para.Text: under SSCBA 1992 or SSCB(NI)A 1992 (or both).
The person’s employment allowance for the tax year is—

P3para.Text: if less, an amount equal to the total amount of the liabilities mentioned in subsection (1)(b) which are not excluded liabilities.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1) is subject to sections 2 and 3 (and Schedule 1).
Sections 2 and 3 (and Schedule 1) set out cases in which a person cannot qualify for an employment allowance for a tax year.
Section 2 also sets out the cases in which liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions are “excluded liabilities”.
Section 4 provides for a person who qualifies for an employment allowance for a tax year to receive it by way of deductions or a repayment under that section.
In this Act references to “the employment allowance provisions” are to this section, sections 2 to 4 and Schedule 1.
In the employment allowance provisions and section 5 terms used which are also used in Part 1 of SSCBA 1992 or SSCB(NI)A 1992 have the same meaning as they have in that Part.
A person cannot qualify for an employment allowance for a tax year if, at any time in the tax year, the person is a public authority which is not a charity.
In subsection (1)—

Para.Text: “charity” has the same meaning as in the Small Charitable Donations Act 2012 (see section 18(1) of that Act), and
“public authority” includes any person whose activities involve, wholly or mainly, the performance of functions (whether or not in the United Kingdom) which are of a public nature.

P2para.Text: Liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions incurred by a person (“P”) are “excluded liabilities” if they are incurred in respect of an employed earner who is employed (wholly or partly) for purposes connected with P’s personal, family or household affairs.

Text.Emphasis: Workers supplied by service companies etc

P2para.Text: Liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions are “excluded liabilities” if they are incurred by virtue of regulations made under section 4A of SSCBA 1992 or SSCB(NI)A 1992 (earnings of workers supplied by service companies etc).
Subsection (6) applies if a business, or a part of a business, is transferred to a person (“P”) in a tax year.

Liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions incurred by P in the tax year are “excluded liabilities” if they are incurred in respect of an employed earner who is employed (wholly or partly) for purposes connected with the transferred business or part.
For the purposes of subsection (5) a business, or a part of a business, is transferred to P in a tax year if, in the tax year—

P3para.Text: another person (“Q”) is carrying on the business or part, and
in consequence of arrangements involving P and Q, P begins to carry on the business or part on or following Q ceasing to do so.

P2para.Text: In subsection (7)(b) “arrangements” includes any agreement, understanding, scheme, transaction or series of transactions (whether or not legally enforceable).
In subsections (5) to (7) “business” includes—

P3para.Text: anything which is a trade, profession or vocation for the purposes of the Income Tax Acts or the Corporation Tax Acts;
a property business (as defined in section 263(6) of the Income Tax (Trading and Other Income) Act 2005);
any charitable or not-for-profit undertaking or any similar undertaking;
functions of a public nature.

P2para.Text: A person cannot qualify for an employment allowance for a tax year if, apart from this subsection, the person would qualify in consequence of avoidance arrangements.

In a case not covered by subsection (10), liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions incurred by a person (“P”) in a tax year are “excluded liabilities” if they are incurred by P, or are incurred by P in that tax year (as opposed to another tax year), in consequence of avoidance arrangements.

In subsections (10) and (11) “avoidance arrangements” means arrangements the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of which is to secure that a person benefits, or benefits further, from the application of the employment allowance provisions.
In subsection (12) “arrangements” includes any agreement, understanding, scheme, transaction or series of transactions (whether or not legally enforceable).
This section applies if—

P3para.Text: at the beginning of a tax year, two or more companies which are not charities are connected with one another, and
apart from this section, two or more of those companies would qualify for an employment allowance for the tax year.

P2para.Text: This section also applies if—

P3para.Text: at the beginning of a tax year, two or more charities are connected with one another, and
apart from this section, two or more of those charities would qualify for an employment allowance for the tax year.

P2para.Text: Only one of the companies or charities mentioned in subsection (1)(b) or (2)(b) (as the case may be) can qualify for an employment allowance for the tax year.
It is up to the companies or charities so mentioned to decide which of them that will be.
Part 1 of Schedule 1 sets out the rules for determining if two or more companies are “connected” with one another for the purposes of subsection (1).
Part 2 of Schedule 1 sets out the rules for determining if two or more charities are “connected” with one another for the purposes of subsection (2).
In this section and Schedule 1—

Para.Text: “charity” has the same meaning as in the Small Charitable Donations Act 2012 (see section 18(1) of that Act), subject to paragraph 8(5) of Schedule 1, and
“company” has the meaning given by section 1121(1) of the Corporation Tax Act 2010 (meaning of “company”) and includes a limited liability partnership.

P1group.Title: How does a person who qualifies for an employment allowance receive it?

P2para.Text: Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs (“HMRC”) must (from time to time) make such arrangements as HMRC consider appropriate for persons who qualify for an employment allowance for a tax year to receive it by making deductions from qualifying payments which they are required to make under regulations made under paragraph 6 of Schedule 1 to SSCBA 1992 or SSCB(NI)A 1992 (regulations combining collection of contributions with tax).

In this section “qualifying payment”, in relation to a person who qualifies for an employment allowance for a tax year, means a payment in respect of any of the person’s liabilities mentioned in section 1(1)(b) which are not excluded liabilities (see section 2).

If under HMRC’s arrangements a person is permitted to make a deduction from a qualifying payment, the person must make the deduction and must make it before any other deductions which the person is permitted to make from the payment under any other legislation.
HMRC’s arrangements may (in particular)—

P3para.Text: require deductions to be made at the earliest opportunity in a tax year;
provide that deductions may not be made in specified cases;
place limits on the amounts of deductions;
provide that a person is not permitted to make deductions unless the person has first given notice to HMRC in such form and manner, and containing such information, as HMRC may require.

P2para.Text: Subsections (6) to (8) apply in relation to a person who qualifies for an employment allowance for a tax year if the person has not deducted under this section the full amount of the employment allowance by the end of the month of April in which the tax year ends.
The person may apply to HMRC for a repayment, up to the outstanding amount of the employment allowance, of qualifying payments made by the person; and HMRC must make the repayment.
The person’s application must be made in such form and manner, and contain such information, as HMRC may require.
The person’s application must be made before the end of the 4th tax year after the tax year mentioned in subsection (5).

In the application of section 102 of the Finance Act 2009 (repayment interest on sums to be paid by HMRC) in relation to a repayment under this section, the repayment interest start date is the date on which HMRC receive the person’s application.

A repayment under this section, and any interest in respect of it under section 102 of the Finance Act 2009, are to be paid out of the National Insurance Fund or the Northern Ireland National Insurance Fund.
A person who qualifies for an employment allowance for a tax year may not receive it otherwise than by way of deductions or a repayment under this section.

P1group.Title: Power to amend the employment allowance provisions

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by regulations amend the employment allowance provisions—

P3para.Text: so as to increase or decrease a person’s employment allowance for a tax year, or

so as to add to, reduce or modify the cases in which a person cannot qualify for an employment allowance for a tax year or in which liabilities to pay secondary Class 1 contributions are “excluded liabilities”.

P2para.Text: Section 175(3) to (5) of SSCBA 1992 (various supplementary powers) applies to the power to make regulations conferred by this section.

The power conferred by section 175(4) of SSCBA 1992, as applied by subsection (2), includes (in particular) power to make the provision mentioned in section 175(4) by way of amendments to the employment allowance provisions.
Regulations under this section must be made by statutory instrument.
A statutory instrument containing (with or without other provision)—

P3para.Text: regulations falling within subsection (1)(a) which decrease a person’s employment allowance for a tax year, or
regulations falling within subsection (1)(b),

P2para.Text: may not be made unless a draft has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.
A statutory instrument—

P3para.Text: which contains regulations falling within subsection (1)(a) which increase a person’s employment allowance for a tax year, and
which does not have to be approved in draft under subsection (5),

P2para.Text: must be laid before Parliament after being made.

Regulations contained in a statutory instrument which is required to be laid before Parliament under subsection (6) cease to have effect at the end of the period of 40 days after the day on which the instrument is made unless, before the end of that period, the instrument is approved by a resolution of each House of Parliament.
If regulations cease to have effect as a result of subsection (7), that does not—

P3para.Text: affect anything previously done by virtue of the regulations, or
prevent the making of new regulations to the same or a similar effect.

P2para.Text: In calculating the period of 40 days for the purposes of subsection (7), no account is to be taken of any time during which Parliament is dissolved or prorogued or during which either House is adjourned for more than 4 days.

Pblock.Title: Application of general anti-abuse rule to national insurance contributions

P1group.Title: GAAR to apply to national insurance contributions

P2para.Text: In Part 5 of the Finance Act 2013 (general anti-abuse rule)—

P3para.Text: references to tax, other than in references to particular taxes, include national insurance contributions, and
references to a charge to tax include a liability to pay national insurance contributions.

P2para.Text: Section 206(3) of that Act (list of taxes to which the general anti-abuse rule applies) has effect as if it included a reference to national insurance contributions.

Section 207 of that Act (meaning of “tax arrangements” and “abusive”) has effect as if, in subsection (4)(a), after “income,” there were inserted “earnings (within the meaning of Part 1 of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits Act 1992 or Part 1 of the Social Security Contributions and Benefits (Northern Ireland) Act 1992),”.

Adjustments to be made in respect of national insurance contributions under section 209 of the Finance Act 2013 (counteracting the tax advantages) may be made by a notice given under paragraph 12 of Schedule 43 to that Act (notice of final decision).
For the purposes of section 210 of that Act (consequential relieving adjustments)—

P3para.Text: if a claim under that section relates to Class 4 national insurance contributions, Schedule 1A to the Taxes Management Act 1970 (as that Schedule applies in relation to such contributions) applies to it, and
if a claim under that section relates to any other class of national insurance contributions, it must be made in such form and manner, and contain such information, as HMRC may require.

P2para.Text: Adjustments to be made in respect of national insurance contributions under that section may be made by a notice given under subsection (7) of that section.

This section has effect in relation to tax arrangements (within the meaning of Part 5 of the Finance Act 2013 as modified by this section) entered into on or after the day on which this Act is passed.
Subsections (9) and (10) apply where the tax arrangements—

P3para.Text: would not have been tax arrangements but for the modifications made by this section, and
form part of other arrangements entered into before the day on which this Act is passed.

P2para.Text: The other arrangements are to be ignored for the purposes of section 207(3) of the Finance Act 2013, subject to subsection (10).
Account is to be taken of the other arrangements for the purposes of that section if, as a result, the tax arrangements would not be abusive.
In this section—

Para.Text: “abusive”, “arrangements” and “HMRC” have the same meaning as in Part 5 of the Finance Act 2013;
“national insurance contributions” means contributions under either Part 1 of SSCBA 1992 or Part 1 of SSCB(NI)A 1992.

P1group.Title: Power to modify application of GAAR to national insurance contributions

P2para.Text: Where a modification is made to Part 5 of the Finance Act 2013 (general anti-abuse rule) that does not apply in relation to national insurance contributions (“the tax only modification”), the Treasury may by regulations—

P3para.Text: make provision for the purpose of applying the tax only modification in relation to national insurance contributions (with or without modifications),
make provision in relation to national insurance contributions corresponding to the tax only modification, or

otherwise modify the general anti-abuse rule, as it has effect in relation to national insurance contributions, in consequence of, or for the purpose of making provision supplementary or incidental to, the tax only modification.

P2para.Text: Regulations under this section—

P3para.Text: may amend, repeal or revoke any provision of an Act or instrument made under an Act (whenever passed or made),
may make consequential, incidental, supplementary, transitional, transitory or saving provision, and
may make different provision for different cases, classes of national insurance contributions or purposes.

P2para.Text: Regulations under this section must be made by statutory instrument.

A statutory instrument containing (with or without other provision) regulations under this section that amend or repeal a provision of an Act may not be made unless a draft has been laid before, and approved by a resolution of, each House of Parliament.

A statutory instrument containing regulations under this section that does not have to be approved in draft under subsection (4) is subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
In this section—

Para.Text: “general anti-abuse rule” has the same meaning as in Part 5 of the Finance Act 2013;
“national insurance contributions” means contributions under either Part 1 of SSCBA 1992 or Part 1 of SSCB(NI)A 1992.

TitleBlock.Title: Employment allowance: rules for determining if persons are “connected”

P1para.Text: This Part applies for the purposes of section 3(1).

P2para.Text: Two companies are “connected” with one another if—

P3para.Text: one of the two has control of the other, or
both are under the control of the same person or persons.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (1) “control” has the same meaning as in Part 10 of CTA 2010 (see sections 450 and 451 of that Act) (and a limited liability partnership is to be treated as a company for the purposes of that Part as applied by this sub-paragraph).
For this purpose, where under section 450 of that Act “C” is a limited liability partnership, subsection (3) of that section has effect as if before paragraph (a) there were inserted—

P3para.Text: rights to a share of more than half the assets, or of more than half the income, of C,

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraphs (1) to (3) are subject to paragraphs 3 to 6.
Paragraph 7 provides for further connections.
In this Part “CTA 2010” means the Corporation Tax Act 2010.

P1group.Title: Companies whose relationship is not one of substantial commercial interdependence

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies for the purpose of determining under paragraph 2(1) if two companies are connected with one another if the relationship between the companies is not one of substantial commercial interdependence.

In the application of section 451 of CTA 2010 for the purposes of the determination, any person to whom rights and duties fall to be attributed under subsections (4) and (5) of that section is to be treated, for the purposes of those subsections, as having no associates.
In determining for the purposes of sub-paragraph (1) if two companies have a relationship of “substantial commercial interdependence”, the following factors are to be taken into account—

P3para.Text: the degree to which the companies are financially interdependent (see sub-paragraph (4)),
the degree to which the companies are economically interdependent (see sub-paragraph (5)), and
the degree to which the companies are organisationally interdependent (see sub-paragraph (6)).

P2para.Text: Two companies are “financially interdependent” if (in particular)—

P3para.Text: one gives financial support (directly or indirectly) to the other, or
each has (directly or indirectly) a financial interest in the other’s activities.

P2para.Text: Two companies are “economically interdependent” if (in particular)—

P3para.Text: they seek to realise the same economic objective,
the activities of one benefit the other, or
their activities involve common customers.

P2para.Text: Two companies are “organisationally interdependent” if (in particular) they have—

P3para.Text: common management,
common employees,
common premises, or
common equipment.

P2para.Text: In determining for the purposes of paragraph 2(1) if a company is under the control of another, fixed-rate preference shares held by a company are ignored if the company holding them—

P3para.Text: is not a close company,
takes no part in the management or conduct of the company which issued the shares, or in the management or conduct of its business, and
subscribed for the shares in the ordinary course of a business which includes the provision of finance.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (1) “fixed-rate preference shares” means shares which—

P3para.Text: were issued wholly for new consideration,
do not carry any right either to conversion into shares or securities of any other description or to the acquisition of any additional shares or securities, and
do not carry any right to dividends other than dividends which—

P4para.Text: are of a fixed amount or at a fixed rate per cent of the nominal value of the shares, and
together with any sum paid on redemption, represent no more than a reasonable commercial return on the consideration for which the shares were issued.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2)(a) “new consideration” has the meaning given by section 1115 of CTA 2010.
In sub-paragraph (1)(a) “close company” is to be read in accordance with Chapter 2 of Part 10 of CTA 2010 (see, in particular, section 439 of that Act).
A company (“A”) is not under the control of another company (“B”) for the purposes of paragraph 2(1) if—

P3para.Text: B is a loan creditor of A,
there is no other connection between A and B, and
either—

P4para.Text: B is not a close company, or
B’s relationship to A as a loan creditor arose in the ordinary course of a business which B carries on.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (3) applies if—

P3para.Text: two companies (“A” and “B”) are under the control of the same person who is a loan creditor of each of them,
there is no other connection between A and B, and
either—

P4para.Text: the loan creditor is a company which is not a close company, or
the loan creditor’s relationship to each of A and B as a loan creditor arose in the ordinary course of a business which the loan creditor carries on.

P2para.Text: In determining under paragraph 2(1) if A and B are connected with one another, rights which the loan creditor has as a loan creditor of A, or as a loan creditor of B, are ignored.
In sub-paragraph (2)(a) “control” has the same meaning as in paragraph 2(1).
In this paragraph—

P3para.Text: “close company” is to be read in accordance with Chapter 2 of Part 10 of CTA 2010 (see, in particular, section 439 of that Act),
“connection” includes a connection in the past as well as a connection in the present and references to a connection between two companies include any dealings between them, and
references to a loan creditor of a company are to be read in accordance with section 453 of CTA 2010.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (2) applies if—

P3para.Text: two companies (“A” and “B”) are under the control of the same person by virtue of rights or powers (or both) held in trust by that person, and
there is no other connection between A and B.

P2para.Text: In determining under paragraph 2(1) if A and B are connected with one another, the rights and powers mentioned in sub-paragraph (1)(a) are ignored.
In sub-paragraph (1)—

P3para.Text: “control” has the same meaning as in paragraph 2(1), and
“connection” includes a connection in the past as well as a connection in the present and the reference to a connection between A and B includes any dealings between them.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if—

P3para.Text: a company (“A”) is connected with another company (“B”), and
B is connected with another company (“C”).

P2para.Text: A and C are also connected with one another (if that would not otherwise be the case).

In sub-paragraph (1)(a) the reference to a company being connected with another company is to that company being so connected by virtue of paragraphs 2 to 6 or this paragraph, and in sub-paragraph (1)(b) the reference to a company being connected with another company is to that company being so connected by virtue of paragraphs 2 to 6.
Two charities are connected with one another for the purposes of section 3(2) if—

P3para.Text: they are connected with one another in accordance with section 993 of the Income Tax Act 2007 (meaning of “connected” persons), and
their purposes and activities are the same or substantially similar.

P2para.Text: In the application of section 993 of the Income Tax Act 2007 for the purposes of sub-paragraph (1)(a)—

P3para.Text: a charity which is a trust is to be treated as if it were a company (and accordingly a person), including in this sub-paragraph;
a charity which is a trust has “control” of another person if the trustees (in their capacity as trustees of the charity) have, or any of them has, control of the person;
a person (other than a charity regulator) has “control” of a charity which is a trust if—

P4para.Text: the person is a trustee of the charity and some or all of the powers of the trustees of the charity could be exercised by the person acting alone or by the person acting together with any other persons who are trustees of the charity and who are connected with the person,
the person, alone or together with other persons, has power to appoint or remove a trustee of the charity, or
the person, alone or together with other persons, has any power of approval or direction in relation to the carrying out by the trustees of any of their functions.

P2para.Text: A charity which is a trust is also connected with another charity which is a trust for the purposes of section 3(2) if at least half of the trustees of one of the charities are—

P3para.Text: trustees of the other charity,
persons who are connected with persons who are trustees of the other charity, or
a combination of both,

P2para.Text: and the charities’ purposes and activities are the same or substantially similar.

In determining if a person is connected with another person for the purposes of sub-paragraph (2)(c)(i) or (3)(b), apply section 993 of the Income Tax Act 2007 with the omission of subsection (3) of that section (and without the modifications in sub-paragraph (2)).
If a charity (“A”) controls a company (“B”) which, apart from this sub-paragraph, would not be a charity—

P3para.Text: B is to be treated as if it were a charity for the purposes of section 3 and this Part (including this sub-paragraph), and
A and B are connected with one another for the purposes of section 3(2).

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (5) “control” is to be read in accordance with—

P3para.Text: paragraph 2(2) and (3) (but ignoring paragraphs 3 to 6), and
sub-paragraph (2)(b) of this paragraph.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if—

P3para.Text: a charity (“A”) is connected with another charity (“B”) for the purposes of section 3(2), and
B is connected with another charity (“C”) for the purposes of section 3(2).

P2para.Text: A and C are also connected with one another for the purposes of section 3(2) (if that would not otherwise be the case).

In sub-paragraph (1)(a) the reference to a charity being connected with another charity for the purposes of section 3(2) is to that charity being so connected by virtue of paragraph 8 or this paragraph, and in sub-paragraph (1)(b) the reference to a charity being connected with another charity for the purposes of section 3(2) is to that charity being so connected by virtue of paragraph 8.
